results.title: G-B 40 driving unit
results.creator_credit: Edward Cook and Big Six Film Unit
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the Huwood Hudswell G-B 40 model mine conveyor unit driving both a top and bottom belt gate conveyor. The complete unit is seen working in a Midlands colliery illustrating that with the acute shortage of manpower existing in the British coal mining industry, equipment such as this is raising the output of each worker.

results.title: G'day: new accents in australian tourism
results.creator_credit: Anne Basser, Colin South and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Changing Australia”.
Tourism is Australia’s largest employer and continues to grow in importance. This program looks at the importance of understanding the cultures our visitors come from and also at the importance of developing foreign language skills for those involved in the tourist industry. We see examples of how Australia can capitalise on the language and cultural skills which already exist within the migrant communities. The program also considers alternative types of tourism, some of which are beginning to involve Aborigines on a more active basis.

results.title: G'day sport
results.creator_credit: Peter Johnson, David Roberts and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Frontiers downunder”.
A slightly different look at a nation that is apparently “sports mad”. This malady and the sort of sporting competition need for most Australians is examined, as well as the extremes that people in the outback go to in order to satisfy their competitive needs

results.title: Futures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Work that was”.
One of a 3 part series on unemployment in Australia, presented by Keith Windschuttle. Looks at the decline of labour intensive manufacturing industries in Australia, and considers whether the coming mineral boom will lead to lower unemployment rates. Also looks at some of the effects that technological change has had on employment, and at a number of local community efforts to decrease unemployment in country towns. Presented by Keith Windschuttle.

results.title: Future wave: Japan design
results.brief_description: This documentary explores, through example and personal reflection, the economics, aesthetics, personalities, and traditional spiritual links that translate so spectacularly into Japanese design.

results.title: Future urban form
results.brief_description: “Summary: attemps to describe, analyse and evaluate certain trends and future possibilities for urban form in britain. two trends are isolated upward extension outward growth. the processes that underlie these trends are the examined. the development of the lift being largely responsible for upward extension, while outward growth is largely associated with the railroad and car. the ideas of a number of visionaries are then examined”

results.title: Future shock
results.creator_credit: Metro Media Corporation and Alex Grasshoff
results.brief_description: Examines the current phenomenon of future shock, the condition which results from too much change too fast. Current technological developments are presented through interviews with scientists. The film echoes Alvin Toffler’s questioning of whether or not change is necessary, and if it is out of control.
results.description: Examines the current phenomenon of future shock, the condition which results from too much change too fast. results.title: Future looks rosy
results.brief_description: Looks at the problems of soil salinity due to erosion and poor agricultural practices. In cooperation with the Department of Conservation, Forests & Land, landholders are seeking solutions to the problem of land degradation.
